name: auto-off insteon-mqtt dimmer (15 min default)
info:
This will turn off an insteon-mqtt type
dimmer light after the default 15 minutes
or set msg.delay for a different number of
integer minutes.

Feed this from an insteon-mqtt state topic
from an mqtt broker
from a DIMMER.
This is dimmer specific because a dimmer's
state is different than a switch,
containing json such as:
 {"state": "ON", "brightness": 155)
vs a switch with just "ON"

it assumes the payload is a json-formatted
string so it first converts from string json
to a json object.

User can again hit dimmer's on anytime during
the on period to restart timer
(if they need more time, for example).

For efficiency, this cancels the timer if they
turn off the dimmer so as not to unnecessarily
continuing timer and sending off to an already
off dimmer.

name: Read Me: Notes (please retain these notes if distributing the flows)
info:
Rainforest Automation Eagle
Author: Mike Thompson, GitHub: mike-linus
Date: 24/2/2016
Date: 2017.05.05 modified byt jeff tapia

These examples show how to extract data and control the Rainforest Eagle using the recommended HTTP Rest API both locally and via the Internet Gateway.

For those of you trying to get the most out of the Rainforest Eagle, these example Node-Red flows should get you going. Having the flows in Node-Red opens up a huge range of automation possibilities. Enjoy :)

To use the flows:
1. Modify the 'Format Request' function nodes to your specific credentials. For local requests, you need to add your own MAC address. For the Relay Gateway, the message headers need to be altered to your Gateway account.
2. For all flows except the Gateway flow, modify the 'http request' nodes, tick  'use basic authentication?', add your 'Cloud ID' as the username, your 'Installation Code' as the password and your Eagle's IP address.
3. For the Gateway flow, basic authentication is not used as the credentials are passed in the message header.
4. To automate the flows, simply modify the 'inject node' to repeat at the required interval.
5. To publish the data on a MQTT topic, just replace the debug node with an MQTT node.

Creating your own commands simply requires creating the appropriate command string in the 'Format request' node. Refer to the Eagle Rest API documentation for more information.

You will have 2 minutes to enter the 4-digit pin into Ecobee.com and authorize the application. (Ecobee disgards the 4-pin code after 10 minutes!)

name: set flow context variables
func:
flow.set("username",msg.username)
flow.set("password",msg.password)

var urlprefix = "http://192.168.1.231:25105/"; //example "http://192.168.1.231:25105/"

var auth = 'Basic ' + new Buffer(username + ':' + password).toString('base64');
var newMsg ={
    "url":urlprefix + "buffstatus.xml",
    "method": "GET",
    headers: {
        'Authorization': auth
    }
};
flow.set('buffurlwithauth',newMsg);
flow.set('urlbase',"http://192.168.1.231:25105/");
flow.set('urlsuffixforbuffstatus',"buffstatus.xml");
flow.set('urlsuffixforbuffclear',"1?XB=M=1");

// new way for context
//var newMsg = Object.create(flow.get('buffurlwithauth'));

/*
jt notes about context:
node level context (just) within a function block or node):
    context.set(''); context.get('');
flow level:
    flow.set(''); flow.get('');
global
    global.set(''); global.get('');
*/

notes on insteon/command/{device} vs insteon/{device}/set
info:
it appears you can set a dimmer device, for example
using either:
 msg.topic = 'insteon/command/{device}''
 msg.payload = '{ "cmd": "on", "level" : 175, "instant" : 1 }''

or:
 msg.topic = 'insteon/{device}/set'
 msg.payload = { "cmd": "on" }

or:
 msg.topic = 'insteon/{device}/level'
 msg.payload = '{ "cmd": "on"[,"level" : 175] }'
 ([]-optional)
 
 I'm unclear which of the 3 might be best.

//flow.set("Ecobee.RedirectURIForAuthorizationMethod","192.168.1.216.xip.io/ecobee/redirect")
flow.set("Ecobee.RedirectURIForAuthorizationMethod","http://tapiafamily.org/ecobee/redirect")
flow.set("Ecobee.StateForAuthorizationMethod","OUR_STATE")

var newMsg ={
    "url":"https://api.ecobee.com/authorize?"+
        "response_type=code&client_id="+flow.get("Ecobee.ClientIDForAuthorizationMethod")+
        "&redirect_uri="+flow.get("Ecobee.RedirectURIForAuthorizationMethod")+
        "&scope=smartWrite"+"&state="+flow.get("Ecobee.StateForAuthorizationMethod"),
    "method": "GET",
    headers: {
    }
};
return newMsg;

/*
GET https://api.ecobee.com/authorize?
        response_type=code&
        client_id=APP_KEY&
        redirect_uri=YOUR_SERVER_URI&
        scope=SCOPE&
        state=YOUR_STATE

GET YOUR_SERVER_URI?
        code=AUTHORIZATION_CODE&
        state=YOUR_STATE


POST https://api.ecobee.com/token?
        grant_type=authorization_code&
        code=AUTHORIZATION_TOKEN&
        redirect_uri=YOUR_SERVER_URI&
        client_id=APP_KEY


{
    "access_token": "Rc7JE8P7XUgSCPogLOx2VLMfITqQQrjg",
    "token_type": "Bearer",
    "expires_in": 3599,

name: Node-RED Public Site - README
info:
This Flow demonstrates how to create
a simple frontend webpage with Node-RED.

The public facing page consists of the 
client side JavaScript, CSS and HTML. 

The important technique is how the mustache 
templates are used. Each template will set the
"property" relative to the content. 

The CSS node sets the "msg.payload.style" property.
The JavaScript node sets the "msg.payload.script" property.
The HTML node then includes these properties 
<script>{{{payload.script}}}</script>
<style>{{{payload.style}}}</style>


This example was created by http://www.InternetofLEGO.com
